note_spans.text: Sarah reports a tough couple of weeks with worsening insomnia[1], now averaging three to four hours of sleep per night.

citations.transcript: Hi. Honestly, it's been a really tough couple of weeks. The insomnia has gotten worse. I'm maybe getting three or four hours a night now, and I feel exhausted all the time.

note_spans.text: She feels exhausted[2] and has been experiencing increased irritability[3], particularly towards her husband and daughter, Emma.

citations.transcript: My mood has definitely been lower. I've been feeling more irritable with my husband and with Emma, which I hate. I snapped at Emma yesterday for something small and then felt terrible about it. I've also noticed I don't really enjoy things the way I used to. Even reading, which I love, feels like a chore.

Complicated. We've always had a difficult dynamic. She's very critical, especially about how I'm raising Emma. Last week she told me I'm too permissive and that's why Emma has tantrums. I know she's probably wrong, but it still hurts. I ended up crying in the bathroom after she left the room.

note_spans.text: Sarah describes her relationship with her mother as complicated and feels deeply affected by her mother's critical comments about her parenting, leading to feelings of sadness and anhedonia.
Sarah appears fatigued[4] and demonstrates a low affect during the session.

citations.transcript: Good afternoon, Sarah. It's good to see you again. How have you been doing since our last session two weeks ago?

note_spans.text: She expresses frustration[5] and guilt regarding her interactions with her mother[6] and her parenting.[7]

citations.transcript: Okay, that sounds good. I know I need to set boundaries with her. It's just so hard. Every time I try, she makes me feel guilty, like I'm being a bad daughter.

It started about a week after our last session. My mom came to stay with us, and things have been really tense. She keeps making comments about my parenting, and I just lie awake at night replaying those conversations.

Complicated. We've always had a difficult dynamic. She's very critical, especially about how I'm raising Emma. Last week she told me I'm too permissive and that's why Emma has tantrums. I know she's probably wrong, but it still hurts. I ended up crying in the bathroom after she left the room.

note_spans.text: There is observable tension in her demeanor when discussing her mother's criticisms[8], and she acknowledges difficulty in maintaining a consistent evening routine due to late-night conversations[9] and phone use.[10]

citations.transcript: It's been all over the place honestly. We usually have dinner around 7, then I help Emma with homework and get her to bed by 8:30. After that, my mom and I often end up talking, which sometimes turns into arguments. By the time I go to bed, it's usually 11 or later, and my mind is racing. I've been scrolling on my phone in bed a lot too, probably until midnight most nights.

It started about a week after our last session. My mom came to stay with us, and things have been really tense. She keeps making comments about my parenting, and I just lie awake at night replaying those conversations.
The jitteriness can be a common side effect. Let's talk about sleep hygiene for a moment. What does your typical evening routine look like now, especially since your mother arrived?

note_spans.text: Sarah is experiencing symptoms consistent with adjustment disorder[11], characterized by sleep disturbances, irritability, and anhedonia.

citations.transcript: You're describing anhedonia - that loss of pleasure in activities you normally enjoy. Combined with the sleep issues and irritability, I want to check in on something. Have you had any thoughts of hurting yourself or not wanting to be here?

note_spans.text: The recent increase in stressors from her mother's visit appears to exacerbate her symptoms. [12][13]

citations.transcript: That sounds like a significant stressor. How is your relationship with your mother typically?

It started about a week after our last session. My mom came to stay with us, and things have been really tense. She keeps making comments about my parenting, and I just lie awake at night replaying those conversations.

note_spans.text: While she denies suicidal ideation, her desire to escape indicates significant distress.
Progress is hindered by her current sleep hygiene practices and emotional responses to familial interactions.
Continue with sertraline as prescribed[14] and discuss potential dosage adjustments with Dr.[15]

citations.transcript: It's good that you're consistent with the medication. Regarding the dose, that's something to discuss with Dr. Martinez. I can include a note about your symptoms in my summary for her. How is the medication sitting with you otherwise? Any side effects?
I'm glad to hear that, and it's clear Emma is a strong protective factor for you. Are you still taking the sertraline as prescribed?

note_spans.text: Implement a structured wind-down routine that includes no phone use after 10 PM[16], breathing exercises, and light reading.

citations.transcript: Exactly. Let's also set up a simple wind-down routine - no phone after 10 PM, the breathing exercise, and maybe some light reading instead of screen time. We'll check in on how all of this is going in our next session. Your homework this week is the 9 PM conversation boundary and the phone-free wind-down routine. How are you feeling about that?

note_spans.text: Set a boundary for evening conversations with her mother, aiming to end discussions by 9 PM. [17][18][19]

citations.transcript: Setting boundaries with family members who trigger guilt is one of the hardest things to do. It's a skill that takes practice. For this week, I'd like you to try one small boundary - maybe ending conversations by 9 PM. We can role-play how to phrase that before you leave today.

There's no wrong way to do it - the goal is just to slow your nervous system down. Let's practice it together right now, and I'll guide you through it. We can also talk about setting some boundaries with your mother around evening conversations. How does that sound?

Exactly. Let's also set up a simple wind-down routine - no phone after 10 PM, the breathing exercise, and maybe some light reading instead of screen time. We'll check in on how all of this is going in our next session. Your homework this week is the 9 PM conversation boundary and the phone-free wind-down routine. How are you feeling about that?

note_spans.text: Follow up on these strategies in the next session to assess effectiveness and make necessary adjustments.
